title: Tuesday, 8th October 2019
bodyHTML:
11:05 am

head great column that

And the companion piece quoting Citi as saying that Corbyn is better (economically) than no deal. https://www.ft.com...-a240-3b065ef5fc55

(If you assume Corbyn doesn't also mean no deal, which isn't a given let's be honest.)

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Wonder if we've got any new "30% probability" guff to quote here? Let me check.

hornblower have any analysts been bold enough to put out new numbers for Ted Baker after the warning last week?
cheeckychappy @BE - I thought Brexit/Politics was a no go area for Markets Live?
2s10s Here is Spectator Brexit scoop, https://blogs.spectator.co.uk/2019/10/how-number-10-view-the-state-of-the-negotiations/
Soundbuy Those claiming they knew what they were voting for must have turbo-charged crystal balls.........
2s10s @cheeckychappy : when did that happen?
BE11:13am

Ah, here's Morgan Stanley.

BE11:13am

We expect the talks to fail, leading to an extension and elections to decide the way forward. But if the UK moves the proposed future EU-UK customs border to the Irish Sea, an October deal is achievable. Parliament may support the UK's new proposals... The UK's current proposals for the Irish border involve a customs border in Ireland and a regulatory border in the Irish Sea for agri-food and industrial goods, as well as a review by the Northern Ireland Assembly of the arrangements every four years. At the moment, with the DUP and most of the Conservative MP supporters of a hard Brexit indicating that they could support such a deal, our estimates suggest that the government might have a majority in parliament for such a deal. …but the EU will not, we think: The EU will likely object, since the UK proposal involves a customs border in Ireland, which the EU see as a violation of the commitment to an open border in Ireland and a risk to peace. Also, while it may agree to some consent process, we do not think that the EU would agree to the DUP having a recurring veto, and it would require ultimate ECJ control over the EU customs union and single market rules. An October deal is possible... However, if the UK moves the proposed future EU-UK customs border to the Irish Sea by the end of this week, we think that a deal could be agreed at the October European Council, since this would effectively be a NI-only backstop deal, which the EU has long said would be an acceptable deal. However, the UK government would then face a greater challenge in securing parliamentary ratification, given Unionist opposition to a border in the Irish Sea. ...but we don't expect one: If the UK does move the customs border to the Irish Sea, the UK government would likely lose the support of the DUP and some of the Unionist Conservative MPs who object to an economic border in the Irish Sea, i.e., within the UK, and would then struggle to ratify the deal. Parliamentary defeat would almost certainly lead to an election in which the Conservatives might be more vulnerable to a challenge from the Brexit party, for favouring a compromise Brexit over an immediate no-deal Brexit. As a result, our base case continues to be no October deal, and the UK requesting an extension ahead of 4Q elections, which will effectively decide the way forward on Brexit. Another UK shift would shift the probabilities away from no deal: At the moment we have the probability of a deal (35%), no deal (35%) and no Brexit (30%) at broadly similar levels. However, if a Johnson government were to switch to supporting a negotiable deal – by agreeing to a customs border in the Irish Sea – then we would see a significantly reduced risk of a no-deal outcome, since even a leave government would prefer a negotiable deal to a no-deal outcome. Our strategists would see a fall in the likelihood of a no-deal outcome as supportive for GBP and UK risk assets.

XYZ9999 easyJet please
11:14 am
BE11:14am

And Goldman.

BE11:15am

We view Prime Minister Johnson’s latest Brexit proposals as an opening offer, not an ultimatum. Although the UK government’s plans for Ireland are clearly unacceptable to the EU in their current form, we think there is political space for both sides to move further into a “broad landing zone” close in substance to the existing Withdrawal Agreement. In terms of the path from here, we maintain our base case that the UK will leave the EU by 31 October with a close variant of the Agreement negotiated under former Prime Minister Theresa May.

PBateman Spectator article explosive
cracklenpop So it's gong to be a khaki election, with the Tories campaigning on a no-deal platform as the Brexit Party 2:0. Sad to see a once-great political party reduced to that.

Which looks .................. uh, well, it's not where my money would be.

11:20 am
Pagegroup PLC (PAGE:LSE): Last: 368.40, down 49.2 (-11.78%), High: 396.80, Low: 356.00, Volume: 753.72k

"the deterioration in trading conditions seen during Q3 across the majority of our regions is anticipated to continue"

BE11:21am

Usual stuff. Worsening macro conditions in Europe, particularly Germany

11:22 am

Signs of slowing growth in the US. Hong Kong not great for obvious reasons. Greater China tariffs.

BE11:23am

So operating profit guidance for FY19 goes down to £140-150m compared to consensus of £156m

Irish HF guy @nightingale20201, difficult to have a conviction is such a complex issue as Brexit. The UK people voted to leave the EU, but had no actual concept of what type of leaving that meant. T May decided is was Rule Britannia Brexit and Boris J has doubled down on this. Add the DUP into the mix and we are here. Personally I think the EU should not agreed to extension and let the UK depart. Mind you, the UK is now out of the EU and will spend the next X years negotiating around what that means, so this is not going away. People are going to be so sick of the UK EU relationship post Brexit, I suppose we will need a new word for this phase!
BE11:23am

Over to Barclays.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Following weakness over the last year, the shares are already reflecting some downgrades. The shares are trading on c11x FY20e PE, c7x EV/EBITA with a c8% FCF yield, big discounts to cross-cycle multiples on all metrics but not trough levels.

BE11:24am

If Germany and the US deteriorated towards flat fees, we see profit being towards the lower end of the range. If they hold up it would be closer to the middle.

· Cost action - Added heads in the UK and attrition was a little lower in Q3, but the overall level is seen as fine. Most of the cutting remains about stopping adding heads and allowing the number to drift lower through attrition. Management is in cost control mode rather than taking more drastic action. What would trigger more aggressive action? US/ Germany slipping into negative territory or a hard Brexit.

Irish HF guy Page Group, I would say competition from Indeed is hurting them in Germany,
BE11:24am

Read-across. We have noted previously that Page is earlier in its downgrade cycle than Hays, so we would not necessarily expect such a negative result when Hays reports next week.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

...... which is ....... mixed news? PageGroup is suffering because it's earlier cycle than Hays, which will suffer later?

BE11:25am

I mean, that's the nature of cyclicals but ......

BE11:25am

RBC:

nightingale20201 @Irish...I sided with you..if UK is not already, it will be a buyer market for at least a few more years...
11:25 am
BE11:26am

Slower than expected Q3, with net fees at £217m vs our estimate of £221.5m (and vs cons £221.4m). Overall LFL net fee growth was 2.1% vs forecast 4.7%
(cons 4.9%) and vs Q2 at 7.4%. It appears the exit rate was broadly flat. The slower growth reflects a tough comparative and subdued markets in UK, HK/China
and some parts of Europe. Europe grew at 5.6% (vs 9% in Q2), Asia at -8.1% (vs 4.7% in Q2), Americas at 13% (17.4% in Q2) and the UK at -4.1% (vs -2.4%
in Q2). Management now expects FY profit to be in the £140-150m range versus consensus around the £156m level, so a c.7% lower at the mid point.
Clearly trading is tough - no real surprise given the weaker macro and employment data of late. However, we continue to be positive, despite the macro
uncertainty, believing the risks are more than factored into the valuation, and would note post the recent weakness, we think the stock is yielding close to 7%,
including specials for 2019. Comparatives get much easier from here (c15pts easier over the next 4 quarters).

BE11:26am

Whilst the macro is tough currently, we see Page as well placed for the longer-term given its geographic diversity and mix. It should be the biggest beneficiary
of wage inflation and skills shortages over time. Valuation is already factoring in a material slowdown and we see the total dividend yield as supportive.

Soundbuy Recruitment - A cyclical industry to be sure.........
2s10s @Soundbuy: yeah but isn't unemployment suppose to be a lagging indicator?
BE11:27am

Meanwhile, in the smalls, same story.

11:27 am
Robert Walters Plc (RWA:LSE): Last: 456.53, down 33.47 (-6.83%), High: 459.00, Low: 430.00, Volume: 26.03k
BE11:28am

Panmure to summarise there:

BE11:28am

Robert Walters, the specialist international white-collar staffer, continues to deliver positive group net fee income growth. However, the rate of expansion has been impacted by the ongoing deterioration in trading conditions in the UK&I division. This slowdown is depressing the group conversion ratio and management now expect full year PBT will be in line with FY18 (implying a 5.4% downgrade). Whilst we remain positive on Robert Walters and maintain our BUY recommendation, we are reducing our 12-month target price to 700 pence. This is just above the 52-week range and equates to 13x FY21 EPS (which we see as the relevant benchmark for a 12-month target price).

11:29 am
BE11:30am

UK's only a quarter of RW's group fees clearly in a bad place.

Soundbuy Suppose you may be cautious with regards to recruitment before you actually have to lay off folk
BE11:30am

Panmure again:

MnM I work as a contractor in the City, and have just been offered a 5% rate cut
BE11:30am

The latest KPMG-REC Report on Jobs (published today 8 Oct) highlighted the slowdown in recruitment. The report indicated that, in September, Permanent placements dropped for the seventh month in a row. Whilst the number of vacancies increased, it was the weakest level of expansion for over seven-and-a-half years. In addition, the availability of staff continues to drop amid an uncertain outlook, which is clearly impacting on candidate confidence. That said, in September there was a modest increase in temp billings (month-on-month basis), with expansion strongest in the regions.
These trends can be seen in the Robert Walters numbers, with net fees contracting 11% during 3Q19 (vs a decline of 8% 2Q19, despite softer comps). The geo-political uncertainty is clearly affecting on both client and candidate confidence, a position we expect will continue for the foreseeable future.

2s10s @MnM: I've been there, several times. Except it was compulsory. I just accepted it, shrugged my shoulders and carried on.
11:31 am
BE11:31am

With the forward P/E (rolling 12-month basis) sitting on a more than 45% discount to its 10-year average investors are clearly pricing in the headwinds caused by Brexit (and indeed other geo-political factors). This rating ignores the growth being delivered elsewhere in the group. Our previous 850 pence target price was based on the assumption that the rating returned to the long-term average. However, until we see a more stable macro environment, we appreciate investor sentiment will stay cautious for a while. Therefore, whilst we remain positive on Robert Walters and maintain our BUY recommendation, we are reducing our 12-month target price to 700 pence. This is just above the 52-week range and equates to 13x FY21 EPS (which we see as the relevant benchmark for a 12-month target price). This forward P/E is in line with the average multiple over the last five years.

Soundbuy So recruitment affected prior to (un)employment (if that makes sense???)
MnM or I can take me chances in the direst of employment markets thanks to Brexit and the impending IR35 changes
BE11:32am

We've done loads of stuff in the past about how recruiter stocks price in the downturn and the upturn 12 to 18 months before it arrives.

LK Hyman @BE "Nine times goes the passing bell" You're not the one saying farewell, I hope?
BE11:34am

The logical conclusion of that process is for recruiters to telescope both the downturn and the upturn and trade at a steady through-the-cycle multiple. But, hey, markets.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Such as Alphavalue.

Tax Realist I make that about 8 bids (possible bids)for LSE since 2000, all failed. Is this a record?
BE11:38am

As a reminder, HKEX made a £32bn takeover bid on the company last month (with only 25% of the operation funded in cash) which was rapidly rejected by the LSE for many reasons (regulatory hurdles, Hong Kong’s political uncertainties, low price and low portion of cash mainly). As we wrote in the title of a Latest at that time, “_A desperate bid…nothing to see_”, the probability was very low for the deal to pass.
In recent days, however, it appeared that HKEX was ready to adjust its offer which benefited LSEG’s share price (about +6% from Thursday to Monday).
The Asian market venue eventually simply dropped its offer, as it has not
convinced LSE’s management nor its shareholders.
Shareholders and management are more comfortable with the Refinitiv deal. Accepting the HKEX deal would have left it at risk of losing on every front (dropping Refinitiv and taking the risk that the HKEX/LSEG deal would fail regulatory approvals). Not showing any interest in the relatively generous offer from HKEX is a sign that LSEG’s shareholders are convinced the Refinitiv deal will create more value. We remain positive on the company on a standalone basis anyway.

chad_john Depends if you include Mike Ashley's numerous Debehhams attempts
Irish HF guy you can buy Schwab on a 14x PE, $0 commissions only affect 6-9% of revenue, or buy TD Ameritrade for 9x PE although 20% of revenues affected by $0 commissions, or you can buy LSE for 20x-25x +. I know what I would be interested in! (US brokerages)! Although interest rates decline does feed thru to profitability!
BE11:40am

Merrill, similarly, retreads why Refinitiv is " financially and strategically compelling" . We've heard it enough over the weeks though, so let's move on.

11:40 am
undefined

EasyJet.

Easyjet PLC (EZJ:LSE): Last: 1,099, down 73.5 (-6.27%), High: 1,147, Low: 1,000, Volume: 1.76m
11:41 am
BE11:41am

Dull outlook and a five-month high yesterday, for no obvious reason.

Patience @2s10s - for 19 years I worked on an industrial estate with only one exit. I found time of peak evening rush a great leading indicator for economy & stock market.
cracklenpop The KPMG-REC Report on Jobs (hiring intentions) is a pretty good lead indicator: https://home.kpmg/uk/en/home/media/press-releases/2019/09/kpmg-and-rec-uk-report-on-jobs.html
BE11:42am

FY guidance is altered microscopically. PTP of £420-430m from £400-440m previously.

BE11:43am

And no guidance whatsoever for the September 2020 year end, because of the obvious.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

There are a few downgrades coming through though they're mostly just fixing stale estimates. Here's JP Morgan.

Tsetse It might be worth asking why the technical issues at gatwick disproportionally affect easyjet when compared to other large airlines that put 60-90 minutes' gap into their schedules rather than 35
BE11:44am

We reduce our FY20 PTP by 6% from £488m to £459m. To be fair BBG consensus is already £453m mean / £463m median, so we are playing catch up. After the Q3 19 update (July 2019) we took a more positive view on EZJ's FY20 RPS outlook because we believe that the delays in
delivering B737 MAX aircraft to EZJ’s competitors (EZJ only operates
Airbus aircraft) will create a tighter capacity situation. We maintain this
view; indeed, the demise of Thomas Cook should provide further
support to EZJ’s RPS. However, we now update our fuel cost forecast
based on recent market moves. We also take a more prudent view on
NFC per seat (constant FX); with a weaker economic backdrop we now
expect EZJ to grow its seats by only 3% (prior est. 4%) and this lower
growth will make it harder to reduce NFC per seat. Lastly it goes
without saying that Brexit provides tremendous uncertainty with the
potential for a better or worse outcome for EZJ's earnings than we
currently project.

A. M. @Tsetse: is the cost of an airport slot proportional to its duration?
BE11:46am

(@Tsetse: I don't know, but imagine that EasyJet like Ryanair and all the discount airlines have no slack whatsoever built into their turnaround times.)

11:46 am
BE11:46am

And Kepler.

BE11:47am

Based on the company’s fuel hedging indication for FY 2020E, we estimate an absolute fuel cost increase of GBP180m in 2019E. easyJet indicates a cost per seat excluding the fuel decline of 0.8% helped by 10.3% capacity growth. We believe it will be harder to achieve a non-fuel cost improvement if capacity growth slows. With our expectation of capacity growth of only 3% in 2020E, we factor in a flat non-fuel unit cost per passenger next year. Our estimates do not account for the potential extra negative impact on the cost base deriving from Brexit next year. We expect flat unit revenues in 2020E. Our 2020E PBT of GBP350m is 23% below Reuters consensus. We value easyJet based on its historical P/E 2020E multiple of 11.3x (the average for the last ten years).

Tsetse @A.M. Not slots, scheduling. Aircraft comes in from X and departs to Y. The trouble is, easyjet schedule half a dozen departures each five minutes first thing and by lunchtime everything is running late. 35 minutes as well as being achievable also prevents them from catching up the delays. By the end of the day, it's EU compensation bonanza time. Whole thing is entirely self-inflicted.
A. M. (@IrishHFguy: re:LSE, could it be that the LSE is the ultimate shovel seller?)
nightingale20201 @cracklenpop (re KPMG/REC Rpts) - thanks
A. M. @Tsetse: thanks.
Irish HF guy @Patience, agreed, if you can accurately capture the data of time to exit etc. more jobs, more traffic obviously!
nightingale20201 @ BE (re EZJ)...a 0.8% fuel improvement with 10.3% capacity growth,....almost price inleastic???
BE11:50am

(@Tsetse: vague memory of one of the airlines saying a while back that delayed takeoffs and turnaround were requiring its pilots to fly faster, to avoid EU compensation stuff, which had the result of burning a lot more fuel than budgeted for. It's a tough old game.)

11:50 am
undefined
Tsetse @BE true to a degree but the marginal increase in speed rarely makes a difference. The holding on the ground and in the air however looks to me like it almost negates the benefit of new gen LEAP engines. Run faster to stand still and at best 20% OTP on certain routes.. all public info.
Patience @Irish HF guy - also short-time vs normal hours vs overtime.

Liberum says buy ITV, as it does habitually.

nightingale20201 @BE (Re; ITV) ...ITV's trading statement is on the same day that Disney launches D+
tangledodyssey A.M. What is "tetris"?
11:55 am
BE11:56am

TV has guided to a -1% to +1% Total Advertising revenues figure for Q3. In the past few quarters, ITV’s guidance on Total Advertising has tended to be conservative so we do think there is a chance that there may be an outperformance of guidance, especially as September may be boosted by Government advertising spending on Brexit. While not all the Government’s reported £100m spending around Brexit will go on pure advertising, a large chunk of it will and there is anecdotal signs that traditional media is benefiting from a large volume of these adverts. We have stated Brexit-related advertising could help boost advertising by low single digits (3%-4%).

Post-short-term, Brexit is likely to be the key determinant of advertising performance. However, anecdotally, there are some signs advertisers may be starting to shift some of their money back into TV from digital due to cost and / or performance issues and, in addition, ITV’s VOD revenues – which are growing double digit – should also give ITV access to the pots of money that sit within digital advertising budgets.

BE11:56am

Which is part two of a note looking at Cellnex's purchase of the Arqiva telecoms division for £2bn

nightingale20201 bad timing....unless ITV has a decent advertising revenue from the RWC....
BE11:57am

Towers, essentially. Telly towers.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

Based on the reported June 2019 for Arqiva’s Telecoms and M2M division, this would represent a 5.3x 10.6x June 2019 revenues EBITDA multiple, although Cellnex is flagging a 2020 EBITDA figure of £170m, which would represent just under a 12x 2020E EBITDA price (there is possibly an issue with legacy and / or central costs, which reflects why EBITDA contribution in 2020 is expected to be lower) .

A. M. (@tangledodyssey: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MXHKKY-Powg)
BE11:57am

We highlighted in our note last month on ITV that its SDN asset - which runs one of the main multiplexes for digital terrestrial channels - could be a source of hidden value if ITV decides to sell and that the closest business model to it was the towers infrastructure business, in which Cellnex and Arqiva operate. Applying the EBITDA multiples to SDN would imply a value of £600m-660m depending on which EBITDA multiple above was applied. This would be slightly below our estimate of SDN’s valuation of £750m-1bn (although £600-660m would still represent 12%-13% of ITV’s market cap) but we would note that SDN's margins are c. 75% vs 50% for the Arqiva telecom unit, so we think SDN should command a higher value.

tangledodyssey Sorry, have never watched the little yellow beings!
marktime We have just had hard data to promote IAG 3% only to be dragged back down by Easyjet "dull outlook". Stupid fickle markets
Tsetse AM I agree. Why airlines don't incentivise the hold is another of those mysteries..
BornCynic Thanks BE / ROTR
11:59 am

Nearly done. What are we missing?

marktime Oh and good to see you LKH where have you been!
BE12:00pm

Regarding FastFT, editorial direction I've no idea. Sorry. They're way over the other side of the new newsroom.

A. M. @Tsetse: well, I have observed that things went relatively well until they've stopped the free hold baggage allowance. Then it was time for the 'this flight is full, we will carry your luggage in the hold -- free of charge' farce.
Irish HF guy @A.M, with the advent of carry on luggage, the airlines estimate that 90 or so bags will fit in the cabin baggage bins, but do not factor in the distribution of carry on bags to seat placement and add peoples inability to fit the bag in properly and their ability to put small bags and coats in the cabin baggage storage bins, you end up with luggage tetris on board any given low cost airline! Not sure if Jet2 is different!
nightingale20201 (Re ITV).... talking about peer group...not sure whether the announcement of S4's (sorrell's new toy) acquisition make any diff to ITV...
A. M. @IrishHFguy: even on not-so-low-cost airlines, unfortunately.
tangledodyssey BE: Many thanks, have a good afternoon.
BE12:02pm

Um .... There's a TalkTalk downgrade from SocGen's Nick Lyall, who's generally very good, but I don't have it to hand.

nightingale20201 fyi. The return of Boeing's 737 Max has been delayed according to WSJ...
